Update on School Lunches and Help During the Summer

Together, we are facing some of the most trying times in our lives during this pandemic. Time is still moving forward and summer is quickly approaching. Our last day for school lunch distribution will be June 1. Also, on June 1, we are expanding our collaborative efforts with Jenny’s Kloset, to bring all district families a children’s produce market sponsored by Weinberg Food Bank. Meats, milk, produce, canned goods and more will be offered curbside every other Monday at the Elementary School starting on June 1. Pick up will be offered from 11am until food supply is exhausted. Jenny’s Kloset will also be offering curbside pick up for urgent needs every Friday at the Elementary School, 10am-12noon, until further notice. If you have an emergent need for food, please contact Jenny’s Kloset at 570-466-0658. Together, we will get through this. Thank you and be safe!

Debbie A Ky‎Valley View Soccer Parents Association
April 30 at 7:59 AM ·

Due to the COVID 19 pandemic, many people have lost their jobs and are in need of some help. The Wright Center for Community Medicine is holding a food drive in May and is looking for donations.

The Valley View Soccer Teams are looking to help. Since it’s hard to find cases of canned goods in stores today to donate, there was a reach out to the players yesterday to see if anyone was interested in donating a can or two per each soccer family to help make a big difference in the lives of someone who needs it.

On Wednesday May 6th after 5 pm some of the kids will be driving around to pick up cans to donate.

This is just an FYI and if you want to help out as well just leave them on your porch or by your mailbox and someone will pick them up.

Either reach out to one of the girls or boys varsity soccer players with your address to forward on to us or you can PM me your address and we will send someone over to pick it up.

⚽️💛💙 VVproud

As a result of the extended closure and updated guidance from the US and PA Departments of Education and the legal community, the Valley View School District will soon be rolling out a continuity of education program for our students. The safety of our students, their families, and our entire community is and always will be our top priority. More information will follow. Thank you for your patience and understanding during this complex and rapidly evolving situation.

As a reminder, we are serving lunches and breakfasts for the following day each day this week from 11-1230 at our HS and ES.

Stay Safe!

Dr. Michael J. Boccella
Superintendent

He has qualified for the International Bridge Building competition to be held in Chicago, Illinois on May 9th. The bridges are constructed using 3/32” x 3/32” bass wood strips with a goal holding a maximum weight load of 100 pounds. The bridge with the highest efficiency wins the competition. Good luck in Chicago Noah!

Valley View Middle School recently held its annual district championship portion of the National Geographic Bee. All students in grades 6, 7, and 8 took a written qualifying test which determined the 25 finalists who competed on stage in front of an audience of students, teachers, and parents until two finalists, and ultimately a champion, were decided.

The bee champion was 8th grader Paul Delicati, son of Paul and Sandy Delicati, Archbald. The runner-up was 8th grader Brayden Baron, son of Bridget Baron and Justin Willis, Peckville. Tying for 3rd place were 8th grader Natalie Fuller and 6th graders Petar Neshkov and Jack Kondrat. Other competitors were Roger Getts, Evan Chilek, Mason Peters, Ella Mattise, Michael Zipay, Joey Bunevicius, Mary Zabielski, Jacob Bekele, Eva Canevari, Ciara Shedd, Brady Skeen, Tommy Fiorelli, Gianni Marino, Jenna O’Malley, Aldair Martinez, Ryder Bronson, Tyler Scoblick, Aidan Kopa, Emma Frey, and Emily Loomis.

That being said, student safety is and always will be our number one priority. We believe this change puts our students' safety first while allowing for as little interruption as possible to their semi. Have fun and be safe!

Elisha DeSouza has been chosen as the 2019-2020 Hugh O'Brien Youth Leader for Valley View High School. He will join over 250 sophomore students across the state of Pennsylvania for a leadership seminar at Shippensburg University, May 14-17, 2020. This annual HOBY event unites students with community leaders, business executives and educators with the goal of fostering teamwork, developing critical-thinking skills and building connections. HOBY is successful in equipping today's youth with the necessary skills to confront the challenges of tomorrow. HOBY's mission is to inspire and develop our global community of youth and volunteers to a life dedicated to leadership, service, and innovation.

Congratulations to Elisha! We look forward to his participation and this unique opportunity.

Left to right: Chris Mendicino, Principal; Elisha DeSouza; Kim Dudrich, Guidance Counselor; and Larry Pegula, Assistant Principal

Valley View High School held a Veteran’s Day assembly on November 8th to honor all of our local veterans. There was a luncheon provided for the veteran's followed by an assembly in the auditorium. Our chorus, Voices of the Valley, Keynote speaker Clyde Brown, and history club officers honored the veterans with music, honorary introductions, and moving speeches. A donation was presented to Bob and Sylvia Tagert, representatives of Equines For Freedom. Equines for Freedom is a nonprofit organization treating active and former military personnel who are experiencing symptoms of Post Traumatic Stress Disorder. A donation of $1,000 was made to the organization. The donation was raised from Veteran's Day t-shirt sales throughout the district.

Maddison Kuzdro, treasurer; Robert Ferraro, secretary; Kayla Davitt, president of history club; Nicole Zeiss, advisor; Sylvia and Bob Tagert, Equines For Freedom; and Nina Grushinski, vice president.

The scholarship is awarded to Jessup residents first, then Valley View students, then Lackawanna county students if previous demographics are not filled.

The Valley View School District will be conducting "School Security Drills" in each of our school buildings this week. A School Security Drill is defined as a planned exercise designed to respond to an emergency situation such as an armed intruder or other violent threat.

It is the procedure of the Valley View School District to inform students of these drills prior to running them. As such, students will be made aware the day of a planned drill.

Again, the exercises happening this week are just drills designed to keep students safe.
